rationale: It was classified into Category 2 from 96-hour LC50=1.2mg/L of Crustacea (Mysid shrimp), and others (CICAD18, 1999).
It was classified as outside of Category since rabbit LD50s were >10 and 10.6g/kg (CICAD 18 (1999), EU-RAR (2001)).

Rat LC50 = 8000ppm (39.3mg/L) (ACGIH (2001)) is more than saturated vapor pressure pressures concentrations (4215ppm), and it was judged to be an examination in mist. It was set as the outside of Category based on the guidance value of mist.
Liquid (GHS definition)

Examination concentration of 3577ppm for 6hr on rat (4hr equivalent: 4381ppm) (ACGIH (2001)) corresponds to Category 4. But it presupposed that it cannot be classified since death is not observed. Moreover, examination concentration of 20mg/L for 4hr on rats (EU-RAR (2001)) corresponds to Category 4. But it presupposed that it cannot be classified since death is not observed.

It was classified into Category 5 based on 2210 mg/kg which was done the statistical culculation of rat LD50 (1400, 4000, 1400, 2910, 2700, 3980, and 4750 mg/kg ((CERI Hazard Data ((1999)), ACGIH ((2001)), EU-RAR ((2001)), and PATTY ((5th, 2001))).

hazard_statement: May be fatal if swallowed and enters airways
rationale: It is a hydrocarbon and dynamic viscosity is not over 20.5mm [2/s ]. And, there was a description "when the fluid is swallowed, there is a risk of chemical pneumonia by aspiration" (ICSC(ICSC(J), (2000))). Moreover, it is classified as R65 in EU. Therefore, we classified it into Category 1.
Since the classifications of EPA were "D and CBD", they classified out of Category.

hazard_statement: Toxic to aquatic life with long lasting effects
rationale: Classified into Category 2, since acute toxicity was Category 2 and not rapidly degrading (BOD: 33% (existing chemical safety inspections data)), though supposed less bio-accumulative (log Kow=3.66(PHYSPROP Database, 2005)).
UNRTDG Class: 3, PG III
There are no chemical groups associated with explosive properties present in the molecules.
Not aerosol products
Liquid (GHS definition)
It was classified as Category 3 based on flash point: 31 degC and UN No.1918 Class: 3 Packing group III.
Liquid (GHS definition)
Liquid (GHS definition)

Based on the two negative results (ACGIH (2001), CICAD 18 (1999), DFGOT vol.13 (1999), EU-RAR (2001)) of the in vivo mouse micronucleus examination, we classified it as Out Of Category. In addition, all in vitro examinations were also negative and the results support the classification as "Out Of Category."
There are no chemical groups associated with peroxide present in the molecule.
Liquid (GHS definition)
Organic compounds containing no oxygen, fluorine and chlorine.
Liquid (GHS definition)
Flash point: 420degC (ICSC, 2000)
Liquid (GHS definition)

classification: Respiratory sensitization: Classification not possible; Skin sensitization: Not classified
rationale: Respiratory sensitization: Since there was no data, it was decided that It could not be classified. Skin seneitization: Based on the two reports (ACGIH (2001) and CICAD 18 (1999)) that no skin sensitization was identified in the  maximization test, it .was put outside of the Category.
Test methods applicable to liquid substances are not available
There are no chemical groups associated with explosive or self-reactive properties present in the molecule.

By two Draize examinations, mild irritation (ACGIH (2001), EU-RAR (2001)), and others, from middle to severe edemas and erythema of the conjunctiva are reported by individual reports (DFGOT vol.13 (1999)).  Except these one, slight irritation or stimulativeness altogether (ACGIH (2001), CICAD 18 (1999), DFGOT vol.13 (1999), EU-RAR (2001)). Moreover, there is a report that it recovers within five days (ACGIH (2001), CICAD 18 (1999)). Furthermore, it is not classified into "eye irritation" according to the EU classification. It classified into Category 2B from these things.

As for rabbits, some show moderate stimulativeness (DFGOT vol.13 (1999)). But most show mild irritation (ACGIH (2001), EU-RAR (2001), and CICAD 18 (1999)), and it was not classified as "skin irritative" in EU. So it was classified as Category 3.
The chemical structure of the substance does not contain metals or metaloids(B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At).

hazard_statement: Causes damage to organs (central nervous system) through prolonged or repeated exposure
rationale: Since the effect to central nervous systems in humans was reported (PATTY (5th, 2001)), it was classified to Category 1 (central nervous systems).

classification: Category 1 (central nervous system); Category 2 (liver, kidneys, blood system); Category 3 (narcotic effects, respiratory tract irritation)
hazard_statement: Cause damage to organs (central nervous system); May cause damage to organs (liver, kidneys, blood system); May cause respiratory irritation or may cause drowsiness and dizziness (narcotic effects, respiratory tract irritation)
rationale: Many influences of a central nervous systems are reported (ACGIH (2001), CICAD (J)18 (1999), EU-RAR (2001), DFGOT vol.13 (1999)), and it was set as Category 1 (central nervous system) from dosage and a guidance value. Moreover, the affect on liver and the kidney (EU-RAR (2001)) and the affect on leukocyte (DFGO vol.13 (1999)) are reported. It was set as category 2 (liver, kidney, blood) from dosage and a guidance value. Furthermore, an anesthetic action (ACGIH (2001), DFGOT vol.13 (1999), EU-RAR (2001)) and respiratory irritation (ACGIH (2001), DFGOT vol.13 (1999)) are reported. It was set as Category 3 (anesthetic action, respiratory irritation).

No developmental toxicity to a neonatal in rat and rabbit examinations is obvious (ACGIH (2001), CICAD 18 (1999), DFGOT vol.13 (1999), EU-RAR (2001), IRIS (2005)). However, since there is no data about the reproductive function and reproductive potential by the exposure in premating, it is considered as it cannot be classified.
